Name: 1:1 mentoring
Description: Students connect with adults in and/or outside of the learning environment for 1:1 mentoring and regular check-in meetings.

Name: à la carte model
Description: A blended learning model in which students take an online course with an online teacher in addition to other face-to-face courses.

Name: accommodations provided to all students
Description: Accommodations traditionally reserved for students with an IEP are available to all students, and teachers proactively identify accommodations that will foster student success.

Name: adult wellness/SEL
Description: Staff have regular opportunities to cultivate their own social, emotional, and cultural competence, collaborate with one another, build trusting relationships, and maintain a strong community.

Name: advancement on mastery
Description: Students advance to new topics when they have demonstrated mastery of previous competencies, rather than advancing with only a minimal passing grade.

Name: all courses designed for inclusion
Description: Students who typically receive pull-out services or instruction in segregated classrooms (e.g., students classified as English Learners, students with disablities) are integrated with appropriate supports in place to support learning, language ability, and full participation in curriculum.

Name: anti-racist practices
Description: The learning environment is building a culture of taking direct action to dismantle policies and practices that create or perpetuate inequality between racial groups.

Name: assessments for agency and self-directed learning
Description: Tests are administered to measure student performance on various dimensions of self-directed learning (e.g., self-awareness, agency, goal-setting and planning, etc.)

Name: assessments for career readiness
Description: The learning environment assesses students' readiness to enter the workforce and pursue a career path.

Name: assessments for deeper learning
Description: The learning environment assesses deeper learning and 21st century skills beyond academic content mastery, e.g. communication, collaboration, critical thinking', etc.

Name: assessments for social-emotional skills
Description: The learning environment assesses social-emotional and non-cognitive skills, e.g., self-management, social awareness, relationship skills, etc.

Name: bilingual assessments
Description: Tests are designed and administered to build on students' bilingual abilities.

Name: blended learning
Description: Students learn both online and in-person, in which both modalities are connected to provide an integrated learning experience, and with some element of student control over the time, place, path, or pace of learning.

Name: career prep and work-based learning
Description: The learning environment offers career-oriented learning opportunities and connections to professionals who reflect students' varied backgrounds and identities, e.g. via career tech and vocational training, interview practice, internships and apprenticeships, job shadows, etc.

Name: co-leadership
Description: The learning environment involves stakeholders in the process of decision-making and communicates how the input gathered from stakeholders informs decision-making. This may include teachers, students, families, community-based organizations, industry-based partners, or others.

Name: community and business partnerships
Description: Partnerships with businesses and the community help to facilitate experiential learning, internships, mentorships, tutoring, etc.

Name: community-based organizations as co-leaders
Description: The learning environment involves community-based organizations in shared decision-making, and communicates how CBO input has informed decision-making. This may include strategies such as offering learning hubs and integrating expertise into schools.

Name: competency framework
Description: A transparent learning framework is used to align learning and assessment. What proficiency looks like at each performance level is available to students and families.

Name: competency/mastery-based education
Description: The learning environment's model is designed to ensure students are becoming proficient by advancing on demonstrated mastery. May include a deliberate focus on student agency, transparent learning expectations, timely/differentiated supports, varied pacing and pathways, meaningful and formative assessment.

Name: culturally responsive practices
Description: Pedagogy and curriculum are designed to support students who have been marginalized to be independent learners. Core barriers to learning for historically marginalized learners are examined and removed.

Name: design thinking process
Description: Students engage in design thinking, a structured framework for identifying challenges, gathering information, generating potential solutions, refining ideas, and testing solutions.

Name: design to meet needs of students who have been marginalized
Description: The learning environment identifies circumstances impacting students who have been most marginalized in order to intentionally design innovations that improve experiences and outcomes for those students. (Students who have been marginalized may include: students with learning differences, students in foster care, students in the justice system, students with low academic performance, students from historically disenfranchised racial and cultural groups.)

Name: disaggregated data on student participation
Description: The learning environment tracks data on the extent to which different groups of students (e.g., by race, gender, disability, socioeconomic status) participate in programs to ensure that students have equitable access.

Name: dual language programming
Description: A form of bilingual education in which students are taught literacy and content in two languages.

Name: early college high school
Description: A hybrid of high school and college, where all students take both high school and college classes simultaneously, earning credit towards a college degree.

Name: enriched virtual model
Description: A blended learning model in which students complete the majority of coursework online at home or outside of school, but attend school (or an alternative to school that is not home) for required face-to-face learning sessions with a teacher.

Name: expanded open hours
Description: The learning environment is open outside of normal hours and during vacations to support learning and offer services.

Name: extended learning opportunities
Description: Students can access credit-bearing learning experiences outside of school (e.g. internship, service learning, training, etc).

Name: families as co-leaders
Description: The learning environment involves families in shared decision-making, and communicates how family input has informed decision-making. This may include strategies such as participatory budgeting, family advisory groups, etc.

Name: family and community support services
Description: The learning environment offers (or partners to offer) social and wraparound support services to meet the needs of families and the community at large, e.g. through adult learning, childcare, family counseling, financial advising.

Name: flex model
Description: A blended learning model in which students move on fluid schedules among learning activities according to their needs. Online learning is the backbone of student learning, and teachers provide support and instruction on a flexible, as-needed basis. In some cases students may have individual schedules set by a teacher or software algorithm that determine which stations they will rotate through (also known as "individual rotation").

Name: flexible facilities & classroom design
Description: Design maximizes for flexibility and student choice, e.g. multi-purpose spaces, moveable walls, furniture can be arranged in different configurations, etc.

Name: flexible staffing & alternative teaching roles
Description: The learning environment makes creative use of human capital, e.g. through a tutor residency model, outside experts, master teachers or teacher mentors, etc.

Name: flipped classroom
Description: A blended learning model in which students learn at home via online coursework and lectures, and teachers use class time for teacher-guided practice or projects.

Name: grading policies focus on mastery
Description: Grades are reported on a standards-based report card, and focus on the specific competencies students are expected to develop.

Name: heritage language course(s)
Description: A course, or set of courses, designed to support reading, writing, and speaking for students' heritage language (defined as a non-English language they have extensive personal, familial, or community connection to). Similar to English language arts for English speakers but created for non-English languages.

Name: hiring for equity and inclusion values
Description: Hiring practices are designed to result in new hires with equity- and inclusion-focused values. The learning environment may employ specific innovations such as: students or community members on the interview committee, equity and positionality rubrics in use, hiring pool stays open until qualified diverse candidates are identified.

Name: individual learner profiles
Description: Profiles extend across multiple years and may include how the student is performing, as well as personal factors like who they are, what inspires them, and how they best learn.

Name: individual learning paths
Description: Students choose unique learning pathways that are relevant to their interests and passions.

Name: industry-based partners as co-leaders
Description:
The learning environment involves industry-based partners in shared decision-making, and communicates how these partners' input has informed decision-making. This may include strategies such as designing career pathways, developing curriculum and assessments, or offering validated work-based learning as a core part of the school's
design.

Name: interdisciplinary
Description: Projects and learning activities develop knowledge and skills across multiple subject areas and highlight connections between subject area domains, with formal collaboration among teachers across subject areas.

Name: interoperable data from multiple technologies
Description: Data from multiple platforms or software programs is integrated in a "data dashboard" reflecting overall student learning and progress.

Name: makerspace
Description: Students can access a space and/or set of tools for use in building and designing creations.

Name: mental health services
Description: The learning environment offers (or partners to offer) comprehensive counseling and mental health services for students.

Name: multi-age classrooms
Description: Classrooms include students of many ages, rather than grouping them by age or grade band.

Name: multi-tiered system of support (MTSS) in academics
Description: The learning environment has an explicit multi-tiered system of support wherein students progress is monitored for all students, and students who are progressing at a slower pace are provided with structured academic interventions aligned to their academic needs with varying tiers of intensity. Progress is tracked in an ongoing manner for all students to inform fluid intervention decisions.

Name: multiple opportunities to demonstrate mastery
Description: Students have more than one opportunity to demonstrate their learning in order to show they have achieved mastery.

Name: no tracked classes
Description: Gifted programs are eliminated and barriers to advanced courses (e.g. AP, IB, honors) are removed so that no student is barred from accessing these opportunities. Remediation takes place throughout the regular scope and sequence so that "lower level" classes are removed.

Name: peer to peer support
Description: The learning environment creates deliberate structures and processes for peer support, e.g. peer mentorship, peer tutoring, peer assessment, accountability partners, etc.

Name: performance based assessment
Description: Students apply knowledge or demonstrate a skill in place of traditional assessment, for example, through portfolios, projects, and other displays of progress toward goals.

Name: physical well being services
Description: The learning environment offers (or partners to offer) comprehensive services to support the physical health and well-being of students, e.g. supports related to nutrition, housing, abuse, bullying.

Name: place-based learning
Description: The school uses local knowledge, skills, issues, heritage, culture, and landscapes as the foundation for studying subjects across the curriculum.

Name: project-based learning
Description: Students learn through answering complex questions or solving for real-world problems (e.g. homelessness in their city, or a marketing challenge faced by a real company). Also called problem-based learning, inquiry-based learning, or learning-by-doing.

Name: reallocation of resources for those most in need
Description: Distributing school resources equitably, so students receive support and resources according to their need rather than every student receiving the same supports. (Example: assigning most experienced and highest skilled teachers to students needing the most help.)

Name: restorative practices
Description: Restorative practices are used to resolve conflict and strengthen relationships among individuals and within communities in ways that are intentionally restorative, developmentally appropriate, and equitably applied. (In contrast to reacting to harmful or hurtful behavior with punishment or suspension.)

Name: SEL curriculum
Description: The learning environment has adopted a formal classroom curriculum for social and emotional learning outside of academic subjects.

Name: SEL integration school-wide
Description: The learning environment integrates social and emotional learning throughout the academic curriculum and other activities (in contrast to a stand-alone SEL curriculum).

Name: self-paced learning
Description: Students determine their own pace in learning rather than being required to move at the same pace as a whole group.

Name: service learning
Description: Students engage in meaningful community service to enrich the learning experience, learn civic responsibility, and strengthen their communities.

Name: social justice focus
Description: The learning environment uses a social justice lens to design curriculum, instruction, policies, and community engagement. This could include work to understand and address large, complex social issues such as poverty, food insecurity, racism, and environmental justice.

Name: station rotation
Description: A blended learning model in which students rotate through stations on a fixed schedule, where at least one of the stations is an online learning station. In some cases the online learning station may be a computer lab (also known as "lab rotation").

Name: student advisories
Description: Small groups of students meet regularly (daily or weekly, over multiple years) with adult advisors to set learning goals, reflect on progress, and build positive relationships.

Name: student-led conferences
Description: Students plan and lead a meeting including parents and teachers to discuss the student's learning, growth, Individual Education Program (IEP) and/or reclassification from English Learner services if applicable. (As opposed to parent-teacher conferences without students present.)

Name: student-led goal setting
Description: Students set and pursue their own learning goals, as well as self-assess their progress.

Name: students access their own data
Description: Students (and families) can access their own learning and assessment data in real time.

Name: students as co-leaders
Description: The learning environment involves students in shared decision-making, and communicates how student input has informed decision-making. This may include strategies such as student advisory councils, input on curriculum and culture-setting, etc.

Name: students develop projects
Description: Students are partners and leaders in designing, implementing, and assessing projects.

Name: students earn industry credentials
Description: Students can earn industry-issued or recognized credentials as a verification of a their qualifications or competence, in fields such as agriculture, hospitality & tourism, health, information technology, etc.

Name: teachers as co-leaders
Description: The learning environment involves teachers in shared decision-making, and communicates how teacher input has informed decision-making. Teachers make decisions in areas such as learning environment success, curriculum, budget, evaluating their colleagues, selecting personnel, and more.

Name: translanguaging
Description: All students are encouraged to use all languages or dialects they know to make meaning, communicate, and participate in schooling without separation of languages (e.g., "English time" vs. "Spanish time"; enforcing English use in shared spaces; or discouraging AAVE and other "nonstandard" English forms).

Name: trauma-informed practices
Description: Adults are trained to recognize and respond to those who have been impacted by traumatic stress, and students are provided with clear expectations and communication strategies to guide them through stressful situations.

Name: tutoring
Description: In high-impact tutoring, students work with a consistent tutor, multiple times per week, in sessions that are integrated with the learning environment's curriculum and schedule (as opposed to a supplemental or out-of-school program).

Name: universal design for learning
Description: The learning environment is designed to proactively meet the needs of all learners by identifying barriers to learning in the design of the environment, not in the student. This helps educators differentiate to effectively instruct a diverse group of students, regardless of whether students have an Individualized Education Program (IEP).
